metadata.case_name: Appellant Dealers v. Superintendent of Taxes, Dhubri and others

facts.text: Appellants are dealers registered under the Assam Sales Tax Act XVII of 1947.
For the account period April 1, 1948 to September 30, 1948, the appellants submitted a return of their turnover which included sales in Assam of all goods other than jute.
The Superintendent of Taxes, Dhubri, summarily assessed the appellants under sub-s. 4 of s. 17 of the Act to pay tax on sales of jute despatched by them to Calcutta during the account period.
Appeals against the order of assessment to the Assistant Commissioner of Taxes and to the Commissioner of Taxes, Assam, proved unsuccessful.
The appellants applied to the Commissioner of Taxes to refer certain questions arising out of the assessment to the High Court in Assam under S. 34 of the Act.

The Commissioner referred the following questions to the High Court: Whether the turnover from 20,515 maunds of jute (item i), 5,500 maunds (item ii), and 25,209 maunds (item iii) is taxable under the Act.

High Court answered each question: Not being a sale within the meaning of sub-s. 12 of s. 2 of the Act, the consignments are not taxable. Observed no opinion on whether they can be assessed under Explanation to sub-s. 12 of s. 2.
Commissioner of Taxes by order dated August 1, 1952, directed the Superintendent of Taxes to dispose of the case in accordance with the judgment of the High Court under s. 32(8) of the Act.

Superintendent of Taxes issued notice on January 30, 1953, directing appellants to produce evidence, contract papers, account books etc. to see if consignments fall within Explanation to sub-s. 12 of s. 2.
Appellants by letter dated March 23, 1953, called upon Commissioner to direct Superintendent not to proceed with the notice.
Appellants petitioned High Court under Art. 226 for writ prohibiting Superintendent from re-opening assessment and quashing Commissioner's order dated August 1, 1952.
High Court summarily dismissed the petition on April 27, 1953.
Appeal to Supreme Court by special leave under Art. 136.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Superintendent of Taxes had authority to re-open the assessment proceedings and issue notice dated January 30, 1953, requiring production of evidence to determine if transactions fall within the Explanation to s. 2(12) after the High Court's opinion.
Whether reassessment proceedings were barred by limitation under the Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court exercised advisory jurisdiction and did not direct assessment or non-assessment; merely opined transactions not sales under s.2(12). Superintendent acted without authority in re-opening.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Assam Sales Tax Act s.32(8); no power under s.19 or s.19A

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellants were registered and filed returns; s.19 not applicable. No notice under s.19A by Commissioner. No revisional order under s.31 setting aside original assessment.
Reassessment barred by three-year limitation from end of period (expired before Jan 30, 1953 notice).

respondent_arguments.text: Superintendent had authority to re-assess in light of High Court observations on Explanation to s.2(12).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Assam Sales Tax Act s.2(12) Explanation; relied on Bombay Trust Corporation case

court_reasoning.text: High Court in advisory jurisdiction opined transactions not sales under s.2(12), not taxable. Commissioner directed disposal per judgment under s.32(8); Superintendent had no authority to re-open without specific power.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Superintendent's notice not supported by authority under the Act.

court_reasoning.text: Appellants registered and returned; s.19 inapplicable. No s.19A notice by Commissioner. No s.31 revisional set aside.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Direction under s.32(8) did not empower re-opening.

court_reasoning.text: Three years from end of period expired before notice; reassessment barred even if power existed.
Bombay Trust Corporation distinguished: there Commissioner exercised revisional power under s.33; here no such exercise.

holdings.text: Superintendent of Taxes acted without authority in issuing notice to re-open assessment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay Presidency and Aden and others v. Bombay Trust Corporation Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: In that case, Commissioner exercised revisional jurisdiction to direct further enquiry; no such exercise here.

statutes_cited.name: Assam Sales Tax Act XVII of 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs assessment, reference to High Court, directions post-reference, reassessment powers and limitation.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for High Court writ petition and Supreme Court special leave appeal.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed, High Court order set aside. Writ issued quashing proceedings commenced by Superintendent's notice dated January 30, 1953. No remand to High Court.
outcome.relief_granted: Writ quashing the notice and prohibiting re-opening of assessment.

key_quotes.text: The Superintendent of Taxes, in our judgment, acted without authority.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on lack of power to re-open.

key_quotes.text: The proceedings for reassessment were clearly barred because the period prescribed for reassessment had expired.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Reason for invalidity due to limitation.

key_quotes.text: Not being a sale within the meaning of sub-s. 12 of s. 2 of the Act, the consignments are not taxable.
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
key_quotes.significance: High Court's opinion triggering the events.
